check.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to do something in order to find out whether something really is correct, true, or in good condition
check.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Check the tiles carefully before you buy them.
A first rule in solving any mystery is to check the facts.
Fill in the cash book carefully and always check your calculations.
Positive test results are double-checked (=looked at twice) to make absolutely sure.
Check that all the doors are locked securely.
Let me just check whether the potatoes are cooked.
They paused to check how the other climbers were getting on.
I checked the typing for errors.
Turn the tap on and check for leaks.
You must check the evidence against other sources and decide if it is reliable.
check.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to ask someone whether something is correct, true, or allowed
check.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: I’m not authorized to give you a refund – I’ll have to check first.
Make a phone call to check that you’re writing to the right person.
Call the factory to check whether the beds can be delivered today.
Check with your doctor before going on a diet.
check.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to suddenly stop yourself from saying or doing something because you realize it would be better not to
check.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: I had to check the urge to laugh out loud.
He grinned, and then checked himself, not wanting to upset Jack.
check.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to stop something bad from getting worse or continuing to happen
check.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: The police are failing to take adequate measures to check the growth in crime.
check.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: to leave your bags at an official place so they can be put on a plane or a train, or to take someone’s bags in order to do this
check.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Any luggage over five kilos must be checked.
check.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to make a mark (✓) next to an answer, something on a list etc to show you have chosen it, that it is correct, or that you have dealt with it
check.translation[0].note_box[0].section: check
to look at something carefully and thoroughly in order to make sure that it is correct, safe, or working properly
I’ll just check the water level in the battery.
The immigration officer checked their passports.
We need to check the building for structural damage.
examine
to look at something carefully and thoroughly because you want to find out something about it
Experts who examined the painting believe it is genuine.
The police will examine the weapon for fingerprints.
inspect
to look at something carefully and thoroughly in order to make sure that it is correct, safe, or working properly, especially when it is your job to do this
The building is regularly inspected by a fire-safety officer.
Some insurance people have already been here to inspect the damage caused by the storm.
go through something
to examine something such as a document or plan from beginning to end, especially in order to check that it is correct
You should go through the contract before you sign.
I’ve finished my essay, but I just need to go through it to check for spelling mistakes.
double-check
to check something again so that you are completely sure it is correct, safe, or working properly
I double-checked all my calculations and they seemed fine.
Travellers should double-check flight information before setting off today.
to examine or use something in order to find out whether it works or what its qualities are, or in order to check that it is satisfactory
Test your brakes to check they are working correctly.
These products have not been tested on animals.
monitor
to carefully watch or keep checking someone or something in order to see what happens over a period of time
Doctors monitored her progress during the night.
Observers have been monitoring the situation in Burma closely.
check.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: say this when someone mentions each thing on a list, to tell them that you have it or have done it
check.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the process of finding out if something is safe, correct, true, or in the condition it should be
check.translation[2].definitions[0].note: health/medical/dental etc check (=a test done to make sure you are healthy)
check.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: I keep a careful check on my blood pressure.
I decided to run a check on all personnel.
Have a check in your bag first and see if it’s there.
a spot check on the accounts
the need for tighter checks on arms sales
Conduct regular checks on your water quality.
check.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: something that controls something else and stops it from getting worse, continuing to happen etc
check.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Higher interest rates will act as a check on public spending.
check.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: a pattern of squares, especially on cloth
check.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: a shirt with brown and black checks
check.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: a list that you are given in a restaurant showing what you have eaten and how much you must pay
check.translation[2].definitions[5].defi: a mark (✓) that you put next to an answer to show that it is correct or next to something on a list to show that you have dealt with it
check.translation[2].definitions[6].defi: the position of the king (=most important piece) in chess where it can be directly attacked by the opponent’s pieces
check.translation[2].note_box[0].section: do a check
I did a quick check of all the windows, locked the door and left.
make a check
One of the nurses makes regular checks during the night.
run a check
You should run a virus check before downloading from the Internet.
carry out/conduct a check
The police carried out a check on the car’s registration number.
have a check
Always have a final check to make sure you’ve got your ticket and passport.
give something a check
I’d like you to give the car a careful check.
keep a check on somebody/something
Keep a check on your baby’s temperature.
go for a medical/dental etc check
She advised me to go for a medical check.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + check
a quick check
A quick check showed that someone had been in the room.
a thorough/careful check
An engineer gave the computer a thorough check.
a routine check
I went to the doctor for a routine health check.
a random check
Customs officials were carrying out random checks on cars.
a regular check
It’s vital to keep a regular check on your bank balance.
a close check
His teacher was keeping a close check on his progress.
a safety/security check
The security checks at the airport can take a long time.
a health/medical check
People over 60 should have regular medical checks.
a background check
The company conducts background checks on security employees.
a credit check
Banks usually do a credit check before they give you a loan.
a spot check
They did a spot check on 160 vehicles to see how many passengers were wearing seat belts.
a spell check
Have you done a spell check on your essay?
check.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: After a minute, she wrote out the check and placed it on the table.
check.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: an examination or investigation of something to see that it is correct, true, or safe and in the condition it should be
check.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: The fund is monitored regularly by carrying out a check of all outgoing payments against the register.
You can get a free safety check on your gas fire from British Gas.
I passed my medical check and was then sent to HQ.
check.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: to watch or examine something regularly to make sure that it is correct, true, or safe and in the condition it should be
check.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: It’s important to keep a constant check on cashflow.
check.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: something that controls another thing and stops it from happening more or getting worse
check.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: Higher interest rates act as a check on government spending.
check.translation[3].definitions[4].exam: The bank may have to raise interest rates further to keep inflation in check.
check.translation[3].definitions[5].defi: the bill you are given in a restaurant at the end of your meal, showing what you have eaten and the cost
check.translation[3].definitions[6].defi: a mark that you put next to an answer to show it is correct or against an item on a list to show that you have dealt with it
check.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: to find out whether something is correct, true, or safe
check.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: Insurance arrangements will be included in the pension scheme, but you should check that cover is adequate.
Employers have the right to check the criminal record of a potential employee.
check.translation[4].definitions[1].defi: to stop something bad from happening more or getting worse
check.translation[4].definitions[1].exam: They welcomed the Bundesbank’s tighter monetary policy to check inflation and provide for a healthier economic recovery next year.
check.translation[4].definitions[2].defi: to hand your bags to someone at an airport so that they will be put on the plane you are going to take
check.translation[4].definitions[2].exam: We checked our baggage and went for a meal.
check.translation[4].definitions[3].defi: to make a mark next to an answer or something on a list to show that it is correct or has been dealt with
